awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  A Novel Approach To STEM Education Through A Personalized Mobile Cooking App For K-8 Students
awd_abstract_narration:
This SBIR Phase II project involves developing a gamified educational platform for use by K-6 students, their teachers and parents. The application allows users to learn about various topics-including STEAM (mainly science and math), nutrition, and geography. The curriculum is culturally sensitive and also compliant with Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) as the students learn to cook recipes from around the world. By engaging students with carefully developed interactive content, the project aims to simultaneously develop a highly practical and useful life skill (healthy cooking), create excitement about learning, and enhance student proficiency in STEAM concepts related to nutrition and global competence, when compared to a traditional school curriculum. The project aims to tackle both the failure in STEAM teaching and the obesity crisis children in the US face today. Its goal is to improve the health, education and happiness of children across the country, which is consistent with the NSF mission to advance the national health, prosperity, and welfare. 


During Phase II, we will develop the current version of the project into a commercially viable educational platform, by incorporating innovative components and features, the importance of which emerged during customer discovery interviews with teachers. The finalized application will include: novel gamification features, class monitoring tools for teachers, an adaptive learning component (for more effective student learning), and an intelligent recommendation system for determining students' latent food proclivities "i.e., food dimensions that children often have a hard time articulating their preferences on, yet which play an important role in determining overall food liking" and providing healthy recipe suggestions tailored to each student's palate. This carefully crafted combination of features is meant to enhance students' learning experience and their engagement with the platform. The finalized platform will be a robust, responsive multiplatform web application that includes a complete set of K-6 lesson plans aligned with national and state educational standards and delivers an individualized learning experience to students. The learning effectiveness of the lesson plans, included scientific concepts, and gamification and personalization features will be thoroughly evaluated through in-class testing, while the recommendation system will involve the use of supervised Machine Learning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This Phase II project developed the original Chef Koochooloo prototype into a commercially viable product for K-5 students by incorporating additional features requested during our customer interviews and ongoing background research and development efforts. At the end of the Phase II project, we now have a complete set of CCSS, NGSS, and ELA/ELD-aligned K-5 lesson plans available through our robust web-based application, which delivers an individualized learning experience. Specifically, we have reached the following key objectives:


Objective 1: Create separate student and teacher versions of the application that are integrated with each other, and create high fidelity portals for different users (100%). This objective has been fully completed. Additionally, we have also created dashboards for schools and school districts.


Objective 2: Enhance current curriculum and develop at least 200 lessons, through the generation of new content (including fifteen new scientific concepts to be taught, new lessons, and more scientific details in existing lessons) aligned with NGSS, CCSS, and NCSS (100%). This objective has been by far exceeded, as we have created a total of 833 lessons (513 in English), to represent 40 different countries and six grade levels (K-5). 


Objective 3: Introduce Spanish lessons and translations (85%). In order to make our application accessible to students worldwide, our goal was to make the lessons on the app available in multiple languages. Both English lessons (513) and Spanish lessons (320) are now available in our first launch of the app with at least 40 country representations, for most of the K-5 grade band. The translation of the remaining English lessons into Spanish will be completed over the next few months.


Objective 4: Enhance the scale and capacity of our system to allow for concurrent use by 300,000 students (100%). This objective has been fully completed.


Objective 5: Implement adaptive learning to customize the learning experience for each student’s individual needs and capabilities (90%).  We have implemented an adaptive learning system that provides personalized recipe recommendations to students and teachers, and whose performance we will continue fine-tuning beyond  the completion of this grant project.   


Accomplishments


We achieved the following goals of the project:


Objective 1: Create separate student and teacher versions of the application that are integrated with each other, and create high fidelity portals for different users. .

Objective 2: Enhance our current curriculum and develop at least 200 lessons, through the generation of new content (including fifteen new scientific concepts to be taught, new lessons, and more scientific details in existing lessons) aligned with NGSS, CCSS, and NCSS.

Objective 3: Introduce Spanish lessons and translations. Concurrently create translations into Spanish of the English content being created. 

Objective 4: Enhance the scale and capacity of our system to allow for concurrent use by 300,000 students.     

Objective 5: Implement adaptive learning to customize the learning experience for each student’s individual needs and capabilities.     

Impact on educators.

Our work on this project helped talented individuals from under-represented groups enter the field of education, cultivate their talent, and pursue higher degrees. Specifically, we focused heavily on recruiting Black and Hispanic professionals, as we aimed to ensure that our curriculum was created to benefit Black and Hispanic students. Hence, we wanted significant portions of the curriculum to be written by Blacks and Hispanics; this is a departure from the prevalent norm of having White males in charge of the curriculum, which often results in educational content that fails to resonate or connect with minority students. One of our most impactful success stories was a female Hispanic recruit, Gabriela Wiborn, who was an unpaid intern in the beginning, and then we switched her to a paid position (via the undergraduate supplement) and onboarded her to do a partnership with the University of Washington. She went from not being sure whether education was the right for her and whether she would be able to finish school to rediscovering her passion for education. She is now completing her graduate studies in education at the University of Southern California. 


We additionally hired multiple employees from lower income population segments, who, until their work with us, had never had the chance to work with people from other countries. We put them in touch with representatives from multiple foreign countries, to discuss issues related to the curriculum and learn about their culture. This created a positive, family-like, and enriching setup, especially for individuals who were feeling isolated during the pandemic. Overall, our efforts helped foster diversity and inclusion, especially for under-represented individuals whose contribution is greatly needed in the field of education.


 


Last Modified: 11/24/2022
Modified by: Layla Sabourian
